name: The Car Buying Experience Quiz | Business World | 10 Questions

questions.text: When you go shopping for a new car, you see a sticker that gives you the MSRP. What does MSRP stand for?
questions.explanation:
Manufacturer's Suggested Retail Price.

	This is the price that the car dealer wants to charge you- and it's too high!

questions.text: As a rule, when buying a new car, is the MSRP a reasonable price for you to pay?
questions.explanation:
No.

	This is an inflated price. Usually, cars sell at MSRP only if they are extremely popular and in limited supply, such as the 2000 Chrysler PT Cruiser.

questions.text: What is the price called that the dealer supposedly paid for the car?
questions.explanation:
Factory invoice price.

	It's a lot less than the MSRP!

questions.text: As a rough rule, what is a reasonable price to expect to pay for a new car?
questions.correct: 5 percent more than the factory invoice cost minus dealer incentives
questions.explanation:
5 percent more than the factory invoice cost minus dealer incentives.

	To calculate a reasonable price for the car, subtract dealer incentives and holdback from the invoice price and offer 5 percent over that.

questions.text: Every car made has a unique number that identifies it. What is this number called?
questions.explanation:
VIN.

	Vehicle Identification Number. You can use it to track important things about the vehicle, such as whether it's ever been sold under a salvage title.

questions.correct: A percentage of the MSRP or invoice of a new vehicle that is paid to the dealer by the manufacturer
options: The deliberate practice of holding popular vehicles back so demand will increase
The practice of not revealing all the information about a car
When you believe that a dealer is not being honest with you
questions.explanation:
A percentage of the MSRP or invoice of a new vehicle that is paid to the dealer by the manufacturer.

	Dealer holdback is generally 2-3 percent. It guarantees the dealer a profit even if they sell the car at factory invoice price.

questions.text: You decide to purchase a new car, fill out all the paperwork, and take the car home. The next day, you decide that you made a terrible mistake. In most states, can you cancel your deal for a hit in your pocket book?
questions.explanation:
Yes.

	There is a U.S. federal "cooling-off" period for many purchases, but that does not apply to motor vehicles. Some dealerships will allow you to return your new purchase, but not without charging you some fees.

questions.text: You are contemplating buying a used car. What is the correct title of the source you can consult to determine prices on such a car?
questions.explanation:
Kelley Blue Book.

	You can find both wholesale and retail prices.

questions.text: Must all used cars be sold with a warranty?
questions.explanation:
No.

	Nope. It is perfectly legal to sell a used car 'as-is'.

questions.text: Some car dealerships offer 'no haggle' pricing. Which of the following dealerships used to sell its cars only at sticker price, without haggling?
questions.explanation:
Saturn.

	Saturn, a division of General Motors, was closed down in 2009.
